alternatives.transcript: I grew up in st. Louis Missouri my parents always told me I didn't like playing with toys I like playing with vacuum cleaner parts it was always drawing things designing things as a kid airplanes cars but you name it really I didn't realize that there was this career called product design hell is just kind of naturally sketching these things when I was 15 my parents give me a car so I built a car smoking was always a

a contentious issue in my family my mom was a doctor specializing in Radiology my mom's father had died of lung cancer when she was very young he smoked a lot I smoked many packs of cigarettes a day and died at a sadly early age

I hated cigarettes every time I picked one up I felt conflicted about it it stuck with me certainly into college when I really became a smoker James and I met while we were in this program at Stanford we ended up working on a lot of projects that had some social or environmental impact part of the program at Stanford is a comprehensive thesis the last year that you're there you spend entire year doing anything you want and that's the hard part we had been spending an awful lot of time together

you're working on each other's projects and even more time eventually just talking about cigarettes this was in 2004 e-cigarettes didn't exist there's 38 million Americans that still smoke their billion people you still smoke globally but 70% of those people want to quit there is a principle that can be applied here called harm reduction which is basically keep the quote good and remove the bat

we saw this as just a huge Public Health opportunity when James and I met with The Thesis Group and our faculty they were really thrilled we had developed this very clear point of view and whatever the product is it should not look like a cigarette that the harm reduction opportunity is there we even had some early demonstrations of that where we took samples of the vapor from our prototypes and we're comparing it to cigarette smoke it's actually burning tobacco's the real problem so it's so it's mostly the combustion and burning

had a really that's what health effects come in we started interviewing people and showing them these prototypes and ultimately with a lot of hand-holding we would have to sit there and kind of tweak them moment-to-moment to get them to work I remember the final one that we had even had this it was like a gear shift mechanism that you had to use to turn it on that's the one yeah this is the one that's

one of several well this is 002 I think we made five to help a lighting James made this carrying case with a built-in Flynn sparker so the early successes that we felt gave us some confidence that we should really give this a run eventually developed a product that we introduced called plume which did okay there was something missing about all the products that we had developed and all the products that were now on the marketplace you would Vape them you would smoke them and not get that sensation of
smoking a cigarette and I knew this personally because even I was still smoking cigarettes
over the years we had accumulated just a ton of knowledge in different disciplines we said okay we're going to build something from scratch from the ground up that's really how we became Jewel
if we build a product that's better than cigarettes that's one thing and it's a great start people want to move past cigarettes
we would hear these anecdotes from 10 years or 20 years smokers they have tried other e-cigarette products and nothing had worked
there's nothing that really compares to the satisfaction of seeing a smoker a long-term smoker pick up Jewel and know that they're never going to go back

we started this project with the firm belief that Innovation could address all the problems associated with smoking I would tell people you know anyone who will listen 50 years from now nobody's going to be smoking cigarettes they're going to look back and think oh my God I can't believe people used to do that and now I think it's actually going to happen much faster in large part because of the progress that we've made
